front.title: Software science revisited

author.organization: Information Technology Laboratory (National Institute of Standards and Technology)

front.abstract: The set of software metrics introduced by Maurice H. Halstead in the 1970's has seen much scrutiny and not infrequent criticism. This article takes a fresh look at these metrics using quantity calculus (the algebra of units) and a new approach to dimensionless units. In this way, it is possible to assign units to the major Halstead metrics in a manner that is logically consistent. However, Halstead's repurposing of counts of software attributes as counts of unobservable mental events leads to a less plausible, more confusing set of metrics for coding effort than for software attributes.
